newsitem.title: USA: U.S. to allow encryption exports for transactions.
newsitem.headline: U.S. to allow encryption exports for transactions.

text.p: The U.S. Commerce Department said on Thursday it would allow the unlimited export of products that include encryption and are specifically designed to support financial transactions.
In general, the United States strictly limits the export of products containing encryption, software that scrambles information and renders it unreadable without a password or software key.
But many companies have complained that the export limits held back the development of electronic commerce over the Internet.
Products covered by the new rule would include direct home banking software offered by banks to their customers worldwide, the Commerce Department said.
But commercially available encryption products used by banks that could also be used for non-financial purposes will not qualify for the new export exemption.

"Today's action supports the rapid growth of secure electronic commerce that relies on a robust security infrastructure," Undersecretary of Commerce William Reinsch said in a speech to the American Bankers Association.
Bankers praised the new export policy.
"This policy is a major step forward for individuals and institutions involved in electronic commerce," Donald Ogilvie, executive vice president of the ABA, said.
